messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: 𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣: A Tractable Representation for Model Counting and Uniform Sampling1footnote 11footnote 1This is an extended version of the paper entitled “The Power of Literal Equivalence in Model Counting” published in the proceedings of AAAI-21 (3851–3859). The author list has been sorted alphabetically by last name; this should not be used to determine the extent of authors’ contributions.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Knowledge compilation concerns with the compilation of representation languages to target languages supporting a wide range of tractable operations arising from diverse areas of computer science. Tractable target compilation languages are usually achieved by restrictions on the internal nodes (∧\land or ∨\lor) of the 𝖭𝖭𝖥𝖭𝖭𝖥\mathsf{NNF}. In this paper, we propose a new representation language 𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣\mathsf{CCDD}, which introduces new restrictions on conjunction nodes to capture equivalent literals. We show that 𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣\mathsf{CCDD} supports two key queries, model counting and uniform samping, in polytime. We present algorithms and a compiler to compile propositional formulas expressed in 𝖢𝖭𝖥𝖢𝖭𝖥\mathsf{CNF} into 𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣\mathsf{CCDD}. Experiments over a large set of benchmarks show that our compilation times are better with smaller representations than state-of-art Decision-𝖣𝖭𝖭𝖥𝖣𝖭𝖭𝖥\mathsf{DNNF}, 𝖲𝖣𝖣𝖲𝖣𝖣\mathsf{SDD} and 𝖮𝖡𝖣𝖣​[∧]𝖮𝖡𝖣𝖣delimited-[]\mathsf{OBDD[\wedge]} compilers. We apply our techniques to model counting and uniform sampling, and develop model counter and uniform sampler on 𝖢𝖭𝖥𝖢𝖭𝖥\mathsf{CNF}. Our empirical evaluation demonstrates the following significant improvements: our model counter can solve 885 instances while the prior state of the art solved only 843 instances, representing an improvement of 43 instances; and our uniform sampler can solve 780 instances while the prior state of the art solved only 648 instances, representing an improvement of 132 instances.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Knowledge compilation and theory approximation",
        "A knowledge compilation map",
        "A survey on knowledge compilation",
        "Query processing on probabilistic data: A survey",
        "Inference and learning in probabilistic logic programs using weighted boolean formulas",
        "Probabilistic sentential decision diagrams",
        "BDD-based boolean functional synthesis",
        "Model Checking",
        "The language of search",
        "Compile!",
        "Decomposable negation normal form",
        "On the tractability of counting theory models and its application to truth maintenance and belief revision",
        "On compiling CNF into Decision-DNNF",
        "Knowledge compilation meets uniform sampling",
        "An improved Decision-DNNF compiler",
        "Conflict-driven clause learning SAT solvers",
        "New advances in compiling CNF into decomposable negation normal form",
        "Dsharp: Fast d-DNNF compilation with sharpSAT",
        "A top-down compiler for sentential decision diagrams",
        "New canonical representations by augmenting OBDDs with conjunctive decomposition",
        "ADDMC: weighted model counting with algebraic decision diagrams",
        "GANAK: A scalable probabilistic exact model counter",
        "Fast sampling of perfectly uniform satisfying assignments",
        "Graph-based algorithms for boolean function manipulation",
        "SDD: A new canonical representation of propositional knowledge bases",
        "Symmetry-driven decision diagrams for knowledge compilation",
        "Knowledge compilation for model counting: Affine decision trees",
        "CUDD: CU decision diagram package release 2.5.0",
        "BuDDy - a binary decision diagram package",
        "Dynamic minimization of sentential decision diagrams",
        "The complexity of approximate counting",
        "Model counting: A new strategy for obtaining good bounds",
        "A scalable approximate model counter",
        "Algorithmic improvements in approximate counting for probabilistic inference: From linear to logarithmic SAT calls",
        "BIRD: engineering an efficient CNF-XOR SAT solver and its applications to approximate model counting",
        "Tinted, detached, and lazy CNF-XOR solving and its applications to counting and sampling",
        "A scalable and nearly uniform generator of SAT witnesses",
        "Designing samplers is easy: The boon of testers",
        "Extending SAT solvers to cryptographic problems",
        "On the use of partially ordered decision graphs in knowledge compilation and quantified Boolean formulae",
        "Constraint-based random stimuli generation for hardware verification",
        "SharpSAT: counting models with advanced component caching and implicit BCP",
        "Preprocessing for propositional model counting",
        "Modeling and Reasoning with Bayesian Networks",
        "Reduced ordered binary decision diagram with implied literals: A new knowledge compilation approach",
        "Maximum model counting",
        "Integrating tree decompositions into decision heuristics of propositional model counters",
        "On the hardness of probabilistic inference relaxations",
        "sharpSAT — counting models with advanced component caching and implicit BCP",
        "Improving model counting by leveraging definability"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in 𝖢𝖢𝖣𝖣: A Tractable Representation for Model Counting and Uniform Sampling1footnote 11footnote 1This is an extended version of the paper entitled “The Power of Literal Equivalence in Model Counting” published in the proceedings of AAAI-21 (3851–3859). The author list has been sorted alphabetically by last name; this should not be used to determine the extent of authors’ contributions., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
